hero.title: MCP With D23 AI
hero.subtitle: Control D23 with your own Model Context Protocol (MCP) server. Define custom tools and business logic without changing your client code.

info.title: What is MCP?
info.description: The Model Context Protocol enables AI assistants to securely connect to external data sources and tools, extending their capabilities while maintaining security and user control.

items.label: Connecting an MCP server with bearer token

sections.title: Protocol Compatibility
sections.content: D23 follows the core MCP specification with the following supported features:

steps.title: Prepare Your MCP Server
steps.description: Ensure your MCP server is publicly accessible and serving over HTTPS.

steps.title: Connect from D23 Chat
steps.description: Use the /mcp connect command in any D23 conversation.

steps.title: Verify Connection
steps.description: D23 will confirm successful connection and show available tools, or display error messages for troubleshooting.

commands.name: Connect with Bearer Token
commands.description: Connect your MCP server with D23 AI. Your MCP server must have a reliable host that accepts the bearer token and returns the user's phone number in the format {country_code}{number} (e.g., 911234567890). This validation is required for authentication.

commands.name: Connect with OAuth
commands.description: For servers supporting OAuth authentication, a browser window may open for consent and authentication.

commands.name: Use a hosted MCP server
commands.description: Connect hosted MCP server using its unique identifier. You can connect to a pre-validated server a user from your org OR yourself has already connected to.

commands.name: Remove a server
commands.description: Remove a trusted MCP server from your list of connected servers.

commands.name: List connected servers
commands.description: List all your MCP server configurations.

commands.name: Disconnect Server
commands.description: Disconnect from a specific MCP server. You can re-enable the server later using the /mcp enable command.

commands.name: Set Diagnostic Level
commands.description: Control the amount of diagnostic information you receive from MCP operations. Available levels: error, warn, info, debug.

commands.name: Disable a server
commands.description: Disable a specific MCP server. This will stop it from connecting to the server but you won't be able to use the server until using the /mcp enable command.

commands.name: Enable a server
commands.description: Enable a specific MCP server. By default, the server you connected to will be enabled.

requirements.title: Validate Tool
requirements.description: Your MCP server must have a validate tool that returns the server owner's phone number in the format: {country_code}{number}

requirements.title: HTTPS Requirement
requirements.description: All endpoints must be served over HTTPS for security. HTTP connections will be rejected.

requirements.title: Prepare for production
requirements.description: Before going live, deploy on a hosting platform such as Vercel, Cloudflare, or any other service. Ensure that the server is publicly accessible so others can connect to it.
